intro: Jaliscoa paleacea, commonly known as the Mexican ghost flower, is a rare and endangered species native to the mountainous regions of Jalisco, Mexico. It is a flowering plant belonging to the nightshade family, Solanaceae, and is characterized by its pale, almost translucent petals. The plant produces small, inconspicuous flowers that bloom at night, attracting specific pollinators such as moths. Due to habitat loss and limited distribution, it is critically endangered and requires conservation efforts to survive. Its unique botanical features make it an important subject for ecological and botanical research.
